attributes.title: Raymond Zuhowski Final Project
attributes.description: Different video types of anti-DUI public service announcements and their impact on college student's decision to drink and drive.

q1.value: Raymond Zuhowski, Madison Pristera, Caitlyn Pritchard, Clare Conry-Murray, Thomas Joseph Harrison, Mackenzie Gillen, Minka Bolognese, Ella Campbell, Patricia Carballo, Sheahan Collins, Christen Dockins, Madeline Eickman, Maura Flynn, Robert Gentilucci, Ryenn Hayes, Amanda Herzig, Tess Hodder, Gabriel Legido, Ann McConnon, Michael McDermott, Alyssa McDougall, Kara McSweeney, Amanda Monetti, Corinne O'Neill, Claire Pier, Allison Quinter, Carley Rose, Lauren Rossi, Ashley Santos, Gabriella Senni, Brendan Steigerwald, Nolan Vagnozzi, Alexa Weber, Samantha Zupko

q2.value: Video type, whether police or peer incidence video, will have an effect on male and female college student's decision to drink and drive. The hypothesis is that female college students will be more impacted by peer incidence videos while males will be more impacted by police incidence videos.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2 (SEX) x 2 (VIDEO TYPE)

q8.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: I am posting a link on social media for participants to follow so they can take the survey. The targeted participants are male and female college students. The survey includes demographic measures of college status, age, and gender, and 2 between-subject measures of the effectiveness of different anti-DUI public service announcements. Participants will be assigned to groups based on the last digit of their phone number.

q11.value: Ideally, I will have 20 per between-subjects groups for a total of 80 participants.

q12.value: Ideally, I will have 20 per between-subjects groups

q13.value: I plan on stopping data collection once 125 participants are reached.

question.value: Video type(police or peer)- 2 levels

IV- Gender: male and female 
DV- Imagine you have driven your car to a night of drinking with your friends. You have had 4 drinks, which is more than you planned on drinking. You do not have money to call an uber or take public transportation. After watching this video, how likely are you to drive your car home?
ANOVA

attributes.title: INFO 4800
attributes.description: Determining the effect of message framing during the COVID-19 crisis on self-reported voting intention.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Comm/Info 4800 - Voting | Message framing effects on intention to vote during COVID-19

other.value: Secondary analysis: we will analyze the reasons that people give for either voting or not voting, to determine if people in one condition who say they are likely to vote give different reasons for voting, and/or if people who say they are not likely to vote give different reasons for not voting, compared to people in the other conditions. This would be in order to see whether our intervention gave people a particular reason to vote or addressed a particular barrier to voting. We would be unable to make a causal claim because we give participants different questions based on whether they say they are likely or unlikely to vote, so this analysis would be exploratory.

sample.value: We have a total budget of $500 and will pay each participant $1.68 and so we will have a total sample size of 500/1.68 = 297, spread evenly across the 3 conditions

analyses.value: For participants’ self-reported likelihood, we will consolidate participants’ answers on a four-points scale (very likely, likely, unlikely, very unlikely) into two categories (likely and unlikely). We will then use Fisher’s exact test to determine if there is a difference between the framing and not framing conditions (one-sided, with framing expected to be higher), and between issues and leadership framing conditions (two-sided) in terms of the proportion of participants who say they are likely to vote. We will consolidate participants’ answers on their perception of the importance of voting and use Fisher’s exact test analogously (so we will analyze the two dependent variables separately). We will also conduct the same tests controlling for whether participants are registered to vote, and whether they have voted in the last 5 years.

outliers.value: Respondents who indicate that they are not eligible to vote in the U.S. at the time of the study, as determined by the first question in the survey, will not be able to participate. We will also exclude respondents who answer “No” to the final question of the survey, which states, “Since you have reached the end of the survey, you will be fully compensated for your time. However, it is vital that we only include responses from people who devoted their full attention to the study. In your honest opinion, should we use your data?” Finally, we will exclude respondents who don’t answer the question, “How likely are you to vote in the 2020 elections?” as this is the main outcome variable being measured.

dependent.value:
Participant’s self-reported likelihood of voting in the 2020 elections. 
Measured on the following scale: very likely, likely, unlikely, very unlikely.

Participant’s perception of how important voting is.
Measured on the following scale: extremely important, important, unimportant, extremely unimportant.

These variables will be measured by asking participants to answer multiple choice questions after being exposed to a message that emphasizes the importance of voting in the upcoming election.

conditions.value: There will be 3 conditions: message with no framing, message with issues-based framing, message with leadership-based framing.

hypothesis.value:
1. Participants who are exposed to a message about the importance of voting given the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic that also has an additional framing (issues or leadership) are more likely to report that they intend to vote in 2020, as compared to those who are exposed to a message that does not have the additional framing. 

2. Participants who are exposed to a message about the importance of voting given the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic that has an additional issue-based framing are more likely to report that they intend to vote in 2020 as compared to those who are exposed to a message that has an additional leadership-based framing.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: The Effects of Tranexamic Acid in Breast Surgery: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
attributes.description:
The primary objective of this study is to determine the effects of tranexamic acid (TXA) on minimizing intraoperative and postoperative blood loss and its sequelae in breast surgery. 

TXA has been well studied in cardiac and orthopedic surgery. Among plastic surgical subspecialties, TXA has been found to reduce blood loss in craniofacial surgery and orthognathic surgery.1 By contrast, there remains a paucity in the literature for its use in breast surgery. A reduction in blood transfusion requirements and postoperative bleeding in breast surgery may reduce operative risks and post-operative complications.

q2.value: It is hypothesized that administration of TXA in breast surgeries reduces the rate of intra-operative and post-operative complications, thus improving patient outcomes.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A systematic review will be performed, and if applicable, a meta-analysis of the literature in concordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidance and EQUATOR network guidelines. The literature review will be performed using Pubmed, Ovid (MEDLINE and EMBASE), CINAHL, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), and Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (from date of their inception to April 2020) with two independent reviewers for screening, full-text review, data extraction, and assessment of risk bias. Expert opinion will be provided from a specialist in the field and to resolve any conflicts of agreement between reviewers. Inter-rater reliability will be calculated using kappa scores.

Risk of bias assessment will be performed using the RoB 2.0 tool (revised tool for Risk of Bias in randomized trials) and ROBINS-I tool (Risk Of Bias in Non-randomized Studies - of Interventions).

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: A systematic review will be performed, and if applicable, a meta-analysis of the literature in concordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidance and EQUATOR network guidelines.

question.value:
Inclusion criteria: Any retrospective reviews, prospective cohort studies, and randomized control trials that administered (or similar antifibrinolytic; topical or IV) in the context of breast surgery (mammaplasty, mastectomy, implant-based breast reconstruction, autologous breast reconstruction, mastopexy, and breast augmentation) will be included in the study. 

Exclusion criteria: Non-breast related studies, non-human studies, or non-English full-text articles will be excluded.
N/A

The main objective of the study is to determine the effects of TXA on intraoperative and postoperative blood loss in breast surgery.

Primary outcomes of interest are: intraoperative blood loss, blood transfusion requirement, drain output, rates of hematoma formation, post-operative complications (i.e. MI, PE, DVT, or strokes), and mortality rate. 

Secondary outcomes are: seroma formation, post-operative iron supplementation, reasons against the routine use of TXA, and cost-effectiveness of TXA.
Measures will be combined into a mean. Please refer to analysis plan section for further details.

If a sufficient number of studies are available, a meta-analysis of the systematic review will be performed. Data will be pooled and assessed for heterogeneity then appropriate statistical analysis will be performed to examine for statistically significant differences between control and TXA groups.

q18.value: Transformation of the data may be required if the data is non-normative

q19.value: The standard of p< 0.05 will be used to determine significance.

q20.value: Data may be excluded if they are significant outliers (such as high Z-scores using residual student test) or if data cannot be extracted from the articles. If data is excluded from our analysis, it will be mentioned in the manuscript.

q21.value: If there is missing data in the study for a single variable, the other variables may still be included if the missing variable does not impact the other variables. It is unlikely the authors will use other statistical means of extrapolating missing data. If incomplete data is present, it will most likely be excluded from the statistical analysis and will be mentioned in the manuscript if it was excluded.

q22.value: It is unlikely there are other confounding factors that will affect our study results (effects of TXA on study outcomes), but an exploratory analysis may be performed if the authors deem it necessary (i.e. sex and hematoma rates).

q23.value:
References:

attributes.title: The role of personality factors in childhood traumatic events’ impact on treatment progress
attributes.description: The treatment of violent offending can be challenging, and high attrition rates are common. At the same time childhood trauma is highly prevalent in incarcerated individuals with violent offences. To date, little research considered childhood trauma as a possible factor contributing to programme attrition for offending populations. This study will examine how childhood trauma is related to treatment progress and which role personality traits play in this relationship.

q1.value: The role of personality factors in childhood traumatic events’ impact on treatment progress

q3.value: The treatment of violent offending can be challenging, and high attrition rates are common. At the same time childhood trauma is highly prevalent in incarcerated individuals with violent offences. To date, little research considered childhood trauma as a possible factor contributing to programme attrition for offending populations. This study will examine how childhood trauma is related to treatment progress and which role personality traits play in this relationship.

q4.value: We hypothesise that childhood trauma may be a contributing factor to lowered treatment efficacy and to higher treatment attrition, which might be mediated by personality characteristics such as borderline and psychopathic traits. We expect that those individuals high on childhood trauma and psychopathic or borderline personality traits will show poorer treatment progress compared to those with low trauma and/or low borderline and psychopathy personality traits. We also expect that personality traits will mediate the negative relationship between the childhood trauma and treatment outcomes.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a longitudinal, observational study using a pre-existing data, which are routinely collected data in the intervention program units.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data has already been collected and it includes any men who enrolled in the Special Treatment Unit Rehabilitation Programme (STURP) between January 2016 and March 2019, including those who have not completed the treatment. We will only include men who agreed to research being conducted with their data as part of enrolling with the STURP programme.

question.value: The data are routinely collected data of the Department of Corrections NZ treatment units (see above) and have been collated and de-identified prior to this project.

q13.value: This study will use an existing dataset of approximately 400 men who have been assessed as high-risk violent individuals (RoC*RoI > 0.7) and have participated in the Department of Corrections’ high intensity programmes (STURP) at the four Special Treatment Units.

question.value:
* The Triarchic Psychopathy Measure (TriPM; Patrick, Fowles & Krueger, 2009)
* Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory (Millon, Davis, Grossman, & Millon, 2009)
* Psychological Reports prepared by STURP psychologists, which were completed at the end of treatment, and include reports on men’s childhood trauma and their treatment progress.

SEM will be used to analyse the structural relationships between observed variables (treatment outcome and childhood trauma) and latent constructs (personality traits).

Mediation analysis will be conducted to assess whether the personality traits moderate the relationship between childhood trauma and treatment outcome. We will assess the direct and indirect effects of childhood trauma experiences for treatment outcome, controlling for the Mediator personality traits, in one analysis for borderline personality traits, in the other one with psychopathic personality traits.

q21.value: p-Values and model fit indices (R squared, BIC and RMSEA)

q23.value: Participants with missing data will be excluded case-by-case, no data interpolation for missing values will be done.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses will be conducted to investigate differences between types of traumatic experiences; as well as possible effects of previous psychological treatments and the length of served sentence before commencing the treatment; and the number of and the age at first conviction.

registration_responses.q1: The role of personality factors in childhood traumatic events’ impact on treatment progress
registration_responses.q3: The treatment of violent offending can be challenging, and high attrition rates are common. At the same time childhood trauma is highly prevalent in incarcerated individuals with violent offences. To date, little research considered childhood trauma as a possible factor contributing to programme attrition for offending populations. This study will examine how childhood trauma is related to treatment progress and which role personality traits play in this relationship.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesise that childhood trauma may be a contributing factor to lowered treatment efficacy and to higher treatment attrition, which might be mediated by personality characteristics such as borderline and psychopathic traits. We expect that those individuals high on childhood trauma and psychopathic or borderline personality traits will show poorer treatment progress compared to those with low trauma and/or low borderline and psychopathy personality traits. We also expect that personality traits will mediate the negative relationship between the childhood trauma and treatment outcomes.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

We will only include men who agreed to research being conducted with their data as part of enrolling with the STURP programme.

attributes.title: Dual-task interference during postural perturbations: a systematic review
attributes.description: This is a systematic review, and possible meta-analysis, exploring dual-task interference during postural perturbations.

q2.value: In this systematic review we will explore how performance on a postural perturbation task (single task) is affected when performed in combination with a secondary task (dual-task). We will also explore how  performance on the secondary task (motor or cognitive) is affected when performed in combination with a postural perturbation task (dual-task).

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: The screening process of 1) title and abstract, and 2) full-text articles will be performed by two review authors who are blinded to each-others decisions until screening is completed.

question.value: The design is a systematic review and meta-analysis. As we anticipate that not all included studies will provide aggregable data, we will perform both qualitative and quantitative syntheses as appropriate.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Searches was conducted in the following electronic databases: PubMed, CINAHL and Web of Science. Other sources also include reference lists of eligible studies and review articles.

During database searches studies were considered for inclusion if they were of cross-sectional design, or where the baseline data from a clinical trial could be extracted and analyzed. Studies were excluded when they were performed on non-humans, or if they were written in other languages than english.

Screening of the retrieved studies were done in two rounds; 1) title and abstract, and 2) full-text, and performed using the web-based tool Rayyan by two reiew authors blinded to each-others decisions.

Eligibility criteria for the experimental condition of interest were where participants had been exposed to an external perturbation, both in single-task condition and while performing a secondary task (dual-task condition). The balance challenge had to be of an acute and unpredicted nature, while participants were either in a standing or walking position, to be considered for inclusion in this review. Studies where participants were exposed to an internal or continuous perturbation were excluded.

q11.value: All studies eligible for inclusion will be included.

question.value:
The primary outcomes are how each of the tasks in a dual task scenario interfere with each other. Therefore, there are two primary questions that will be evaluated:
Dual-task interference on reactive postural control measures in response to postural perturbations combined with a secondary task.

Examples of reactive balance measures
- Muscle onset latency (EMG)
- Kinematic data, such as center of pressure (CoP), margin of stability (MoS), center of mass (CoM), step length, step latency etc.
Dual-task interference on secondary task (cognitive and/or motor) measures in response to being performed in combination with postural perturbations.
Examples of secondary task measures
- Reaction times
- Correct responses

*Note: dual-task interference commonly presented in percentages.

Descriptive statistics will be used to provide a narrative syntesis of the study-, participant- and exposure characteristics, as well as results of the main outcome (dual-task interference). When a minimum of two studies within comparable populations (ie healthy, neurological, orthopedic etc) provide aggregable and comparable data a meta-analysis will be performed.

registration_responses.q2: In this systematic review we will explore how performance on a postural perturbation task (single task) is affected when performed in combination with a secondary task (dual-task). We will also explore how  performance on the secondary task (motor or cognitive) is affected when performed in combination with a postural perturbation task (dual-task).

attributes.title: Massage for gastrointestinal function after abdominal surgery

q2.value: Massage is effective and safe for gastrointestinal function after abdominal surgery.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will be a systematic review and meta-analysis of all  studies  to assess the effectiveness and safety of massage for gastrointestinal function in patients with abdominal surgery.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
1. Search strategy
We will search the following electronic databases regardless of publication date or language, inlcuding the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE, Chinese BioMedical Database (CBM), China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Chinese VIP Information (VIP), Wangfang Database.
2. Selection of studies 
To determine the studies to be searched further, two review authors  will independently scan the titles and abstracts of all articles identified from electronic databases. Full-text articles will be scanned for all potentially relevant articles. If there is any disagreement on the selection of articles, they will be discussed with the third author.
3.Data extraction and management
For all studies included, two review authors will independently extract the relevant information using a standard data extraction table. Information will include publication of year, author, participants, intervention, control, duration of intervention, outcomes and methodological characteristics. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion by arbiter.

1. The primary outcome is the time to first defecation.
2. The second outcomes include  the time to first passage of flatus, the time to first bowel movement sound, the time to tolerance of solid food, and adverse events.

Continuous variables will be reported as mean difference (MD) with 95% CIs. For different measurement scales, standardized mean difference (SMD) analysis with 95% CI will be used. Categorical variables will be summarized as risk ratios (RR) or odds ratio (OR) with 95% CIs. All analysis will be performed based on the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. Heterogeneity will be identified by visual inspection of the forest and tested by standard chi-squared statistic and a significance level of 0.1. Additionally, the I2 statistic will be used to examine heterogeneity for quantifying inconsistency in the included studies. Fixed or random effects models will be performed in meta-analysis. If I2 >0.5, random effects models will be used.

q21.value: For insufficient or missing data, we will contact the authors by e-mail or phone as much as possible. All analysis will be performed based on intent-to-treat (ITT) principle.

q22.value: Subgroup analysis will be performed in order to explore the differences in the methodological quality, race/ethnicity and type of operation. Sensitivity analysis will be performed in order to test the robustness of findings if there are sufficient studies included.

registration_responses.q2: Massage is effective and safe for gastrointestinal function after abdominal surgery.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q21: For insufficient or missing data, we will contact the authors by e-mail or phone as much as possible. All analysis will be performed based on intent-to-treat (ITT) principle.
registration_responses.q22: Subgroup analysis will be performed in order to explore the differences in the methodological quality, race/ethnicity and type of operation. Sensitivity analysis will be performed in order to test the robustness of findings if there are sufficient studies included.
registration_responses.q6.question: This study will be a systematic review and meta-analysis of all  studies  to assess the effectiveness and safety of massage for gastrointestinal function in patients with abdominal surgery.

2. Selection of studies 
To determine the studies to be searched further, two review authors  will independently scan the titles and abstracts of all articles identified from electronic databases. Full-text articles will be scanned for all potentially relevant articles. If there is any disagreement on the selection of articles, they will be discussed with the third author.
3.Data extraction and management

Information will include publication of year, author, participants, intervention, control, duration of intervention, outcomes and methodological characteristics. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion by arbiter.

1. The primary outcome is the time to first defecation.
2. The second outcomes include  the time to first passage of flatus, the time to first bowel movement sound, the time to tolerance of solid food, and adverse events.
registration_responses.q17.question: Continuous variables will be reported as mean difference (MD) with 95% CIs. For different measurement scales, standardized mean difference (SMD) analysis with 95% CI will be used. Categorical variables will be summarized as risk ratios (RR) or odds ratio (OR) with 95% CIs. All analysis will be performed based on the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. Heterogeneity will be identified by visual inspection of the forest and tested by standard chi-squared statistic and a significance level of 0.1. Additionally, the I2 statistic will be used to examine heterogeneity for quantifying inconsistency in the included studies. Fixed or random effects models will be performed in meta-analysis. If I2 >0.5, random effects models will be used.

attributes.title: A Scoping Review of Interpersonal Social Capital in the Context of Cardiometabolic Disease across the Lifespan in US Dwelling Hispanics/Latinxs
attributes.description:
Hispanics/Latinxs are a historically oppressed ethnic group in the United States (US). They face myriad socioeconomic and health burdens when compared with their non-Hispanic/Latinx White counterparts including less educational attainment, lower income, more workplace injury, less access to health care, less access to healthy food and spaces for physical activity, and greater rates of diabetes mellitus. Yet, despite this considerable hardship, they demonstrate lower age-adjusted all-cause mortality and lower atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease incidence and mortality.

The reasons for this health paradox are not well understood. Many scholars have hypothesized that this paradox may be partially explained by Hispanics'/Latinxs' collectivist values that may facilitate protective family and social dynamics, or interpersonal social capital. However, little is known about the nature of these dynamics and how they may influence disease incidence, management, and progression- particularly, cardiometabolic disease such as diabetes mellitus and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. To address this gap in knowledge, the proposed scoping review will identify and explore studies that measure social environments among US dwelling Hispanics/Latinxs and their association with cardiometabolic disease incidence, management, and progression. Social environments include marital-like relationships, family dynamics surrounding support behaviors, social networks, neighborhood social factors such as integration and cohesion, etc. 

REVIEW QUESTIONS
1.	To identify studies that measure aspects of interpersonal social capital in Hispanics/Latinx living in the US. 
2.	Describe and critically analyze how these constructs are measured. 
3.	Describe how these aspects of interpersonal social capital affect/influence incidence, management, and progression of cardiometabolic disease. 
4.	Identify gaps in the literature and make recommendations for future research.

q2.value: This scoping review is exploratory.  Broadly we expect interpersonal social capital (in its many forms) to significantly affect the incidence, management, and progression of cardiometabolic disease. We do not specify a direction.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
SEARCHES
Searches will included studies that were published in English only. The search will be carried out using six online databases: MEDLINE, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), and PsycINFO. Reference sections from studies included in this review will be searched for any additional studies that meet review criteria. The authors will continue to track citations for any additional studies throughout the duration of the review. 

SELECTION CRITERIA 

STUDIES This scoping review will include all quantitative studies including randomized clinical trials, longitudinal studies, and observational studies. This review will not include studies using solely qualitative methods.  

PARTICIPANTS This study will focus on Hispanics/Latinxs dwelling in the United States.  There is no age restriction for this study. Indeed, there may be studies where a diverse sample of individuals are included in a study (e.g. non-Hispanic Blacks/African Americans and other non-Hispanics groups, etc.) in addition to Hispanics. These studies will only be included if the effects within Hispanics are described separately from aggregate samples. 

RELEVANT PARTICIPANT CORRELATES
This scoping review will extract and incorporate if the following are reported:
•	Nativity
•	Acculturation
•	Gender
•	Education
•	Income
•	SES
•	Insurance status
•	Urban vs rural
•	Comorbidities

TYPES OF OUTCOME MEASURES
Studies will be included if the primary outcome is cardiometabolic disease incidence, management, or progression and a social environmental factor as defined above is included as a predictor. Cardiometabolic diseases include atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, insulin resistance or sensitivity, glucose control or management (HbA1c), diabetes (Type 2), obesity/overweight, and metabolic syndrome and its indicators (high blood pressure/hypertension, high blood sugar/glucose, high visceral fat/abdominal fat, waist-hip ration, low HDL cholesterol, high triglycerides, and insulin resistance), and fatty liver disease.  

DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS AND RISK OF BIAS
Two researchers will independently assess quality of identified manuscripts. When disagreements arise regarding selection of papers for inclusion, an additional review author will be consulted for discussion. If data appears to be missing or in need of clarification, authors of identified manuscripts will be contacted. 

Once the appropriate manuscripts are chosen and verified by both researchers, a narrative synthesis of this literature will be used to discuss how protective family and social dynamics, or interpersonal social capital is related to incidence, management and progression of cardiometabolic disease in Hispanics/Latinxs. A developmental approach (beginning with a synthesis of literature on young children to literature involving older adults) will be used to structure this scoping review. 

INCLUSION CRITERIA
•	US dwelling individuals with a self-reported ethnicity of Hispanic, Latino, Latina, Chicano, Chicana, Latinx, Chicanx (any race) at risk for or with cardiometabolic disease
•	Any age
•	Any studies that use quantitative methods to measure social environments (as defined above)

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: This study is a scoping review of existing literature.

q11.value: Sample size is not relevant here.  We will search the literature using a systematic approach described above.  The number of studies that will fit our search criteria is currently unknown.

q13.value: Searches will continue to be updated throughout the writing process.  This process is expected to take 18 months from May 25, 2020.

question.value: NA

Social Variables (Predictors)
Social environments including marital-like relationships, family dynamics surrounding support behaviors, social networks, neighborhood social factors such as integration and cohesion, etc. will be included in search terms.  

Cardiometabolic Disease Variables (Outcomes)
Studies will be included if the primary outcome is cardiometabolic disease incidence, management, or progression and a social environmental factor as defined above is included as a predictor. Cardiometabolic diseases include atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, insulin resistance or sensitivity, glucose control or management (HbA1c), diabetes (Type 2), obesity/overweight, and metabolic syndrome and its indicators (high blood pressure/hypertension, high blood sugar/glucose, high visceral fat/abdominal fat, waist-hip ration, low HDL cholesterol, high triglycerides, and insulin resistance), and fatty liver disease.
A formal, qualitative synthesis of any literature fitting our protocol will be conducted.  No quantitative analysis will be done.

Two researchers will independently assess quality of identified manuscripts. When disagreements arise regarding selection of papers for inclusion, an additional review author will be consulted for discussion. If data appears to be missing or in need of clarification, authors of identified manuscripts will be contacted. 

Once the appropriate manuscripts are chosen and verified by both researchers, a narrative synthesis of this literature will be used to discuss how protective family and social dynamics, or interpersonal social capital is related to incidence, management and progression of cardiometabolic disease in Hispanics/Latinxs. A developmental approach (beginning with a synthesis of literature on young children to literature involving older adults) will be used to structure this scoping review.

q19.value: In this scoping review we plan to examine both significant and null effects in the existing literature. Significant effects include any 95% confidence intervals that do not contain zero, or are greater or less than one (if an odds ratio or hazard ratio). We will consider p-values less than 0.05 as significant as well. However, we will interpret these with caution as p-values may be influenced by sample size.  We will also synthesize null findings of the relationship between social capital and cardiometabolic disease outcomes.

q20.value: Two researchers will independently assess quality of identified manuscripts. When disagreements arise regarding selection of papers for inclusion, an additional review author will be consulted for discussion. If data appears to be missing or in need of clarification, authors of identified manuscripts will be contacted.

q21.value: If data appears to be missing or in need of clarification, authors of identified manuscripts will be contacted.

q22.value: This scoping review is exploratory.  While we have some idea what we might find (see hypothesis), are primary aim is to synthesize the existing literature according to our protocol (research questions).

If data appears to be missing or in need of clarification, authors of identified manuscripts will be contacted. 

Once the appropriate manuscripts are chosen and verified by both researchers, a narrative synthesis of this literature will be used to discuss how protective family and social dynamics, or interpersonal social capital is related to incidence, management and progression of cardiometabolic disease in Hispanics/Latinxs. A developmental approach (beginning with a synthesis of literature on young children to literature involving older adults) will be used to structure this scoping review. 

INCLUSION CRITERIA
•	US dwelling individuals with a self-reported ethnicity of Hispanic, Latino, Latina, Chicano, Chicana, Latinx, Chicanx (any race) at risk for or with cardiometabolic disease
•	Any age
•	Any studies that use quantitative methods to measure social environments (as defined above)
registration_responses.q10.question:
SEARCHES
Searches will included studies that were published in English only. The search will be carried out using six online databases: MEDLINE, Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), and PsycINFO. Reference sections from studies included in this review will be searched for any additional studies that meet review criteria. The authors will continue to track citations for any additional studies throughout the duration of the review. 

SELECTION CRITERIA 

STUDIES This scoping review will include all quantitative studies including randomized clinical trials, longitudinal studies, and observational studies. This review will not include studies using solely qualitative methods.  

PARTICIPANTS This study will focus on Hispanics/Latinxs dwelling in the United States.  There is no age restriction for this study. Indeed, there may be studies where a diverse sample of individuals are included in a study (e.g. non-Hispanic Blacks/African Americans and other non-Hispanics groups, etc.) in addition to Hispanics. These studies will only be included if the effects within Hispanics are described separately from aggregate samples. 

RELEVANT PARTICIPANT CORRELATES
This scoping review will extract and incorporate if the following are reported:
•	Nativity
•	Acculturation
•	Gender
•	Education
•	Income
•	SES
•	Insurance status
•	Urban vs rural
•	Comorbidities

TYPES OF OUTCOME MEASURES
Studies will be included if the primary outcome is cardiometabolic disease incidence, management, or progression and a social environmental factor as defined above is included as a predictor. Cardiometabolic diseases include atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, insulin resistance or sensitivity, glucose control or management (HbA1c), diabetes (Type 2), obesity/overweight, and metabolic syndrome and its indicators (high blood pressure/hypertension, high blood sugar/glucose, high visceral fat/abdominal fat, waist-hip ration, low HDL cholesterol, high triglycerides, and insulin resistance), and fatty liver disease.  

DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS AND RISK OF BIAS
Two researchers will independently assess quality of identified manuscripts. When disagreements arise regarding selection of papers for inclusion, an additional review author will be consulted for discussion. If data appears to be missing or in need of clarification, authors of identified manuscripts will be contacted. 

Once the appropriate manuscripts are chosen and verified by both researchers, a narrative synthesis of this literature will be used to discuss how protective family and social dynamics, or interpersonal social capital is related to incidence, management and progression of cardiometabolic disease in Hispanics/Latinxs. A developmental approach (beginning with a synthesis of literature on young children to literature involving older adults) will be used to structure this scoping review. 

INCLUSION CRITERIA
•	US dwelling individuals with a self-reported ethnicity of Hispanic, Latino, Latina, Chicano, Chicana, Latinx, Chicanx (any race) at risk for or with cardiometabolic disease
•	Any age
•	Any studies that use quantitative methods to measure social environments (as defined above)
registration_responses.q14.question: NA
registration_responses.q15.question:
Social Variables (Predictors)
Social environments including marital-like relationships, family dynamics surrounding support behaviors, social networks, neighborhood social factors such as integration and cohesion, etc. will be included in search terms.  

Cardiometabolic Disease Variables (Outcomes)
Studies will be included if the primary outcome is cardiometabolic disease incidence, management, or progression and a social environmental factor as defined above is included as a predictor. Cardiometabolic diseases include atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, insulin resistance or sensitivity, glucose control or management (HbA1c), diabetes (Type 2), obesity/overweight, and metabolic syndrome and its indicators (high blood pressure/hypertension, high blood sugar/glucose, high visceral fat/abdominal fat, waist-hip ration, low HDL cholesterol, high triglycerides, and insulin resistance), and fatty liver disease.
registration_responses.q16.question: A formal, qualitative synthesis of any literature fitting our protocol will be conducted.  No quantitative analysis will be done.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Two researchers will independently assess quality of identified manuscripts. When disagreements arise regarding selection of papers for inclusion, an additional review author will be consulted for discussion. If data appears to be missing or in need of clarification, authors of identified manuscripts will be contacted. 

Once the appropriate manuscripts are chosen and verified by both researchers, a narrative synthesis of this literature will be used to discuss how protective family and social dynamics, or interpersonal social capital is related to incidence, management and progression of cardiometabolic disease in Hispanics/Latinxs. A developmental approach (beginning with a synthesis of literature on young children to literature involving older adults) will be used to structure this scoping review.
